messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Polynomial algorithms for p-dispersion problems in a planar Pareto Front

Paper Abstract: Abstract. In this paper, p𝑝p-dispersion problems are studied to select p⩾2𝑝2p\geqslant 2 representative points from a large 2D Pareto Front (PF), solution of bi-objective optimization. Four standard p𝑝p-dispersion variants are considered. A novel variant, Max-Sum-Neighbor p𝑝p-dispersion, is introduced for the specific case of a 2D PF. Firstly, 222-dispersion and 333-dispersion problems are proven solvable in O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) time in a 2D PF. Secondly, dynamic programming algorithms are designed for three p𝑝p-dispersion variants, proving polynomial complexities in a 2D PF. Max-min p𝑝p-dispersion is solvable in O​(p​n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑝𝑛𝑛O(pn\log n) time and O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) memory space. Max-Sum-Neighbor p𝑝p-dispersion is proven solvable in O​(p​n2)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛2O(pn^{2}) time and O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) space. Max-Sum-min p𝑝p-dispersion is solvable in O​(p​n3)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛3O(pn^{3}) time and O​(p​n2)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑛2O(pn^{2}) space. These complexity results hold also in 1D, proving for the first time that Max-Sum-min p𝑝p-dispersion is polynomial in 1D. Furthermore, properties of these algorithms are discussed for an efficient implementation and for practical applications.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The discrete 2-center problem",
        "Lagrangian solution of maximum dispersion problems",
        "Investigating and exploiting the bias of the weighted hypervolume to articulate user preferences",
        "Discrete representation of the non-dominated set for multi-objective optimization problems using kernels",
        "The skyline operator",
        "Maximum volume subset selection for anchored boxes",
        "Two-dimensional subset selection for hypervolume and epsilon-indicator",
        "Faster distance-based representative skyline and k-center along Pareto Front in the plane",
        "A comparative study of efficient initialization methods for the k-means clustering algorithm",
        "Location on tree networks: p-centre and n-dispersion problems",
        "Maximizing dominance in the plane and its applications",
        "Multi-objective optimization for a strategic ATM network redesign problem",
        "Approximation algorithms for clustering to minimize the sum of diameters",
        "k-medoids clustering is solvable in polynomial time for a 2d Pareto front",
        "Clustering a 2d Pareto Front: p-center problems are solvable in polynomial time",
        "Unified polynomial dynamic programming algorithms for p-center variants in a 2D Pareto Front",
        "k-medoids and p-median clustering are solvable in polynomial time for a 2d Pareto front",
        "Parallel matheuristics for the discrete unit commitment problem with min-stop ramping constraints",
        "Matheuristics to optimize refueling and maintenance planning of nuclear power plants",
        "Multiobjective combinatorial optimization - theory, methodology, and applications",
        "Advanced dynamic programming",
        "The discrete p-dispersion problem",
        "Comparison of four models for dispersing facilities",
        "Indicator-based multi-objective evolutionary algorithms: a comprehensive survey",
        "Parametric search and locating supply centers in trees",
        "On metric clustering to minimize the sum of radii",
        "Bounds on multiprocessing timing anomalies",
        "Fast exact k-means, k-medians and Bregman divergence clustering in 1d",
        "The hypervolume indicator: Problems and algorithms",
        "Dispersing facilities on a network",
        "Improved complexity bounds for location problems on the real line",
        "Comparing local search initialization for k-means and k-medoids clustering in a planar Pareto Front, a computational study",
        "Programming models for facility dispersion: The p-dispersion and maxisum dispersion problems",
        "Hypervolume subset selection in two dimensions: Formulations and algorithms",
        "On the unified dispersion problem: Efficient formulations and exact algorithms",
        "Selecting stars: The k most representative skyline operator",
        "Taking the big picture: representative skylines based on significance and diversity",
        "The planar k-means problem is NP-hard",
        "Linear-time algorithms for linear programming in R3 and related problems",
        "On the complexity of some common geometric location problems",
        "New results on the complexity of p-centre problems",
        "Output-sensitive peeling of convex and maximal layers",
        "MBSE, PLM, MIP and Robust Optimization for System of Systems Management, Application to SCCOA French Air Defense Program",
        "Upper bounds and exact algorithms for p-dispersion problems",
        "Heuristic and special case algorithms for dispersion problems",
        "A new compact formulation for the discrete p-dispersion problem",
        "Measuring the quality of discrete representations of efficient sets in multiple objective mathematical programming",
        "Faster k-medoids clustering: improving the PAM, CLARA, and CLARANS algorithms",
        "Archivers for the representation of the set of approximate solutions for MOPs",
        "A min-max theorem for p-center problems on a tree",
        "Fast parallel GPU-sorting using a hybrid algorithm",
        "Metaheuristics: from design to implementation, volume 74",
        "Obnoxious facility location on graphs",
        "Comments on the paper:‘Heuristic and special case algorithms for dispersion problems’ by SS Ravi, DJ Rosenkrantz, and GK Tayi",
        "Skydiver: a framework for skyline diversification",
        "A study on two geometric location problems",
        "A clustering procedure for reducing the number of representative solutions in the Pareto Front of multiobjective optimization problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 57 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Polynomial algorithms for p-dispersion problems in a planar Pareto Front, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
